'Carbon-12' is the more abundant of the two stable isotopes of the element
carbon, accounting for 98.89% of carbon; it contains six protons, six neutrons
and six electrons. Its abundance is due to the Triple-alpha process by which it
is created in stars.

Carbon-12 is of particular importance as it is used as the standard from which
atomic masses of all nuclides are measured: its mass number is 12 by definition.
